title: Law and War
description:
Law and War (20370). 3 units. The class will trace the legal status of war from the time of Grotius to today. It will examine the impact of the change in the legal status of war on everything from the law of armed conflict, to economic sanctions, to unilateral humanitarian intervention (recently considered in Syria), to Russia's intervention in Crimea, to counterterrorism efforts the world over. We will also consider what legal tools exist for enforcing international law when military force is not available. Supervised Analytic Writing and Substantial Paper credit available. Paper required. Enrollment limited to sixteen. Permission of the instructors required. O. Hathaway and S.J. Shapiro.

Course Selection Information: In addition to listing this course among permission-of-instructor selections, students should submit a CV and brief statement of interest by the close of the early registration period on June 26.
